Award.AwardTitle: STEM Practice-rich Investigations for NGSS Teaching (SPRINT)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

STEM Practice-rich Investigations for NGSS Teaching (SPRINT) is an exploratory project that will research and develop resources and a model for professional learning needed to meet the demand of implementing the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS). The Exploratorium Teacher Institute will engage middle school science teachers in a one-year professional learning program to study how familiar routines and classroom tools, specifically hands-on science activities, can serve as starting points for teacher learning. The Teacher Institute will use existing hands-on activities as the basis for developing "practice-rich investigations" that provide teachers and students with opportunities for deep engagement with science and engineering practices. The results of this project will include: (1) empirical evidence from professional learning experiences that support teacher uptake of practice-rich investigations in workshops and their classrooms; (2) a portfolio of STEM practice-rich investigations developed from existing hands-on activities that are shown to enhance teacher understanding of NGSS; and (3) a design tool that supports teachers in modifying existing activities to align with NGSS.

SPRINT conjectures that to address the immediate challenge of supporting teachers to implement NGSS, professional learning models should engage teachers in the same active learning experiences they are expected to provide for their students and that building on teachers' existing strengths and understanding through an asset-based approach could lead to a more sustainable implementation. SPRINT will use design-based research methods to study (a) how creating NGSS-aligned, practice-rich investigations from teachers' existing resources provides them with experiences for three-dimensional science learning and (b) how engaging in these investigations and reflecting on classroom practice can support teachers in understanding and implementing NGSS learning experiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
STEM Practice-rich Investigations for NGSS Teaching (SPRINT) engaged secondary science teachers in a year-long professional learning program to understand how familiar routines and classroom tools, specifically hands-on science activities, could serve as starting points for teacher learning about the three-dimensional learning described in the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS). The project documented the development of NGSS-aligned, practice-rich investigations and teachers’ participation in those investigations both in professional learning settings and in their classrooms. The two major goals for this project were to better understand:

  • How to design professional learning opportunities that support teacher understanding of three-dimensional science learning
  • How that understanding supports their development and enactment of NGSS-aligned classroom investigations

The project created and studied a professional learning model that emphasized engagement in three-dimensional learning as a productive resource for teachers’ sensemaking of NGSS. The project also resulted in a portfolio of STEM practice-rich investigations to use in professional learning activities as well as a planning tool to support teachers in modifying their existing activities into three-dimensional investigations.

Across the two years of the project, 53 secondary science teachers directly interacted with professional learning developed in this project. Results from the project indicate that teachers’ experience as science learners in three-dimensional science investigations provided them with productive resources as they planned three-dimensional science activities for their classrooms. Teachers’ understanding of the needed shifts to their practice developed over the course of the year of professional learning activities and as they implemented NGSS-aligned investigations in their classrooms. Specifically, they began by defining NGSS as an integration of science content and practices and by the end of the year highlighted the need to make more time for student sensemaking and agency in the classroom.

The professional development model, resources, and tools continue to be used in various professional learning contexts to support both teachers and professional learning providers to modify existing inquiry-based activities to align to NGSS and implement three-dimensional learning in their classrooms. The outcomes of this research-practice partnership highlight the value of such collaborations to advance the knowledge of the field as well as the sustained implementation of best practices beyond the life of the project. Future work will study how this professional learning model can be scaled to support a distributed network of teachers working across a range of contexts with diverse populations of students.
